author: A_Brickset_user
title: lovely fort
review: Ahh, i remember getting in love with this set when i was a child. The queen, the green baseplate -it was the first time lego used this raisedplates-, the beatiful bardings , armored knights and the ghost... I was really impressed. But i realised its walls were a bit low. Anyway this is a very good set.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: My first LEGO set
review: This is my first Lego set when I was a child.My mother bought this set for me & my sister.I was so excited to get this.After 15 years,now I am 25 years old.I want to buy this set again,because it is so meaning for me!!

author: legotrainfan
title: Quite some things to criticise
review:
By buying this set you get lots of crossbows. The two big brown doors that come after the drawbridge are also very nice. What I find cool are the ghost and the place where the treasure is hidden. You find the treasure some studs away from the prison. There's a special door on the floor made with hinges and plates. You can lift the door and there it is. And don't forget there's a trapdoor in the tower. Furthermore, the princess is a nice and rare minifig. So this castle has some nice features indeed.

Now my criticism: you cannot attach other castles to it. Well, there is a 1x2 brick with a hole on the left side of the drawbridge. There you can add other castles. But there's no such brick and a pin on the other side. Then there is quite a big opening after the brown doors on the left. The opening is big enough for a minifig to get into the castle and out of it. That's how Robin Hood and his friends always got in and out when I was playing with this set. It should not have been made so easy for Robin Hood! ;-) Half of the castle - where the prison is - looks quite bare. The wall could have been made higher by using castle walls. There's a lack of castle walls anyway. You only find four castle walls in it and six corner castle walls. Not much for such a set. And you don't get many minifigs. Two more minifigs would have been great.

author: Novelty
title: Demi Moore
review:
First off, this set is the first of the castles on a CRAPP and it's the first castle that departs from the previous by not being able to unhook and attach futher wall pieces to form a bigger castle.  That's the only downside to it.

The castle is generally very well designed, and uses the ramp and the pit rather masterfully to create a visually stunning castle.  Everything from the drawbridge to the tower is well designed and visually pleasing and there are little extras all over the place like the secret wall that swings open in front to reveal the ghost (or a soldier).  There's a garden in this castle, a first for a castle set and a princess to go along with it.  The sad thing is that the jail cell (which is just a barred door from Pirates) is located in the garden, so this set has the jail cell with the best view.  The garden also hides the treasure chest below it, which is clever.

Overall a good design, well thought out, visually good looking, and a radical departure from previous castles.

author: justrock
title: Only Castle
review: I was never into the Castle series, but this was one of the few sets to catch my eye, and the only one I actually got. It is just a cool little castle with a neat layout thanks in part to an interesting base plate.

author: MEGADETH
title: old school lego rules
review: This one of the first lego i ever played with, and at the time its really a great castle, the rise plate, the building, ghost, horse saddle, it just awesome. For those who start playing lego in late 90 or 2000 probably think its not good enough but for old school lego fans this is awesome set! its a turning point compare to previous big castle in 80's, you can see it on the castle structure.

author: StormSworder
title: One of the best castle sets.
review:
This is a great set, shows how Lego bricks and a raised baseplaste can work together well.  The lower part of the fort includes a drawbridge, a hidden place for a treasure chest and a window which swings open to reveal a ghost (or a soldier with a crossbow or sword ready to deal with intruders if you don't like fantasy-based sets).

 

The tower includes a trap-door, bars at the back which can be opened, and there are battlements aplenty and a prison cell for any of Robin Hood's men (who presumably won't be feeling so merry at this point).  It's worth noting one of the pillars on the left side of the model has a technic pin, so this castle can be used with the modular castles and castle walls of the 1980s.

 

As minifigs go, this set has a good selection.  There are two knights on horseback, several soldiers with a mixture of chainmail and emblem-fronted torsos and a medieval lady.  Included also are plenty of weapons.  A perfect set.

author: hustla187
title: Another Great Lego Castle
review: This isn't the best Lego Castle, but it's one of the best Lego has ever made. I like the way the drawbridge comes down so the horse can go across which is very cool. Also, I like the fact that Lego put some tree pieces around the castle, which is great. There are alot of minifigs in this set and this set will make you play with this for hours. Overall, this is a legendary set.

author: nicker94
title: One of Legos best castles!
review:
This is one of my top 3 favorite Lego castles mainly because of it's unique design. There is no gatehouse present in the design so therefore there is no gate(portcullis) present unlike many recent castles that try to employ a gate without a gatehouse. I really liked the raised base plate and the inclusion of a princess with unique details was great! Little details like the torches added lots to the set. Cross bows were new at the time and I thought they were designed really well. 

The only cons to this set are minor but they don't keep me from giving it a 5/5. I didn't like the trap door in the tower and I thought that space could have been used as a room for the princess with a bed etc. I always thought the opening wall portion at the front front of the castle was a bit weird but I guess it's a neat idea in some ways. 

Overall this set was really good and probably one of Legos best!

author: Huge_Nerd
title: an all-time favorite!
review: As a kid I wanted a castle so bad and I got this one for Christmas--it did not disappoint! The soldier minifigs are great. The knights are awesome, especially the more ornate one. The princess and ghost make for great adventures as do the secret passages and hidden treasures. A jail is always fun too. I especially like the working draw bridge and the crossbow emplacement on top of the tower!

author: AETerry
title: King's Mountain Fortress Review
review:
This was one of my first actual Castles that I'd gotten and I remember being very excited by it that year at Christmas time, especially as that time of the year or birthdays are when I could hope to expect big sets like this.

 

The Castle does indeed make a departure from Castle sets prior to this one in that it's built ona base plate... a green version of the base plate introduced with the Pirate's theme Eldorado Fortress. Whereas other Castles had been built so you could "snap" the back open to expand/open out the walls to access the interior.

 

One of the trees included makes use of the Palm Tree trunks from Pirates to make a desidious tree rather then a pine or fir tree. This set too is one of the first to feature a ghost and has a rare Queen or Princess Minifigure.

 

8 Minifigures in all make up the set, I count the ghost as one of the minifigures. 2 horses, a black bird using the parrot mold. 2 of the minifigures are wearing the then new plate armor and helmets with visors that move up or down. There's a bunch of crossbows that could be gotten from this set, six in total.

 

Part of the castle on the front opens up so you can hide the ghost within it. Drawbridge, jail and a trap door type deal to place the treasure chest in and guard.

 

In all this was a very enjoyable set and fun to play with.

author: Gpep
title: My childhood set!
review:
I got this set from my parents when I was a child, along with set 6039, and it immediately became my favorite. I could play with it for hoursm and did so for years. The horses, the saddles, the knights, the ghost, the secret doors and the prison cell, just amazing!

 

I gave it away when I was older, in recent years I started to regert it until I finally bought it back on eBay, fortunately it was as good as new and my life is complete again :-).

 

No other set for me.

author: Ernst
title: Simply a great Fortress !
review:
Overall 5 bricks: Again a superb Castle set that deserves the full 5 bricks. A great building on a raised base plate, now with  2 tree's and 8 great mini figures and, like all old castles, great to built. Not for the youngest fans, I estimate a minimum age of 7-8 years to built this fortress.

Building 5 bricks : The start with the sides and the underground treasure chamber and hiding room is very good. I love the entrance, no fence but 2 wooden doors with the usual drawbridge. The built in prison is useful but basic. In and outside walls with both big panels and small bricks, a good mixture, the sides small bricks only. The firm hedge with bars on the backside is a great escape way just like the Ghost hide out in the front. Nice looking solid main tower.

Parts 4 bricks: why distract one brick here ? Because although elsewhere all 5 bricks I have some minor complaints. How to get into the main tower since there are no stairs and a small ladder as in set 6061 is not present either. And the side walls are in my opinion at least on brick too low which makes it very easy to enter the fortress sideways. On the other hand a compliment for the mini figures, especially for the ghost and the Princess.

Playability 5 bricks: all is present for a good time, no arguments against this set.

Value 5 bricks: the average Bricklink gives is at this moment € 65,00 which is ok for a great set like this. I paid even less so no complaints.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
After six years of waiting for a new Castle the Crusaders are finally rewarded with one (on a raised base, which was something of a novelty at the time). The Black Raven and Princess are unique to this set but whereas the previous castle featured 30 wall panels this set only featured four, the ghost should also be noted as a nice inclusion at the time.

I always saw this as the keep and the previous castle as the outer wall and they go very nicely together, it should also be noted that this was the first moulded castle (many of which were to follow) and as such it was a trendsetter, the green added a great variation to the grey and as such this is one of the nicer looking castles from this era. 

If you like this review or if you wish to see images of alternate builds for this set and other sets for this faction click on the link to find it and all reviews of the Castle sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/08/lego-castle-crusaders-sets-1984-1992.html

author: lordjim13
title: Style over Substance
review:
So, this for me was where it all started to go downhill with Lego Castles, and in general. I was a kid in the 80s, and built some awesome Castle MOCs, to be sure.  This was a greatly anticipated Christmas present, as usual, but I think I was almost instantly disappointed. The building and playability aspects, for me, were greatly diminished by the change in design philosophy towards gimmicks (glow-in-the-dark ghosts) and 'cool looking' sets rather than ones you could build and incorporate into other things.

First, as other reviewers have pointed out, while the castle looks pretty awesome from the angle on the box cover, the back is hardly even there. There is an arcade of wide arches behind the gateway that render it pointless to raise the drawbridge, as well as at the back of the tower. Maybe it's a sheer cliff over there they don't need to defend, but it's just a bit lame.

Second, this has the result of cutting down the usable pieces, in favour of the massive, moulded base-plate.  For example, 6080 King's Castle has 674 pieces, and this has 435--the same as Black Falcon's Fortress (and more of those are useful). It's pretty cool itself, and I had fun building proper castles on it afterwards, but basically it was a cop-out and future sets would follow this example (6086 was at least more walled at the front, but still had holes in the rear, while 6091/8, etc are just jokes). More and more Lego substituted big single pieces for more complex and interchangeable designs, and this was the start of the decline for me...

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Justified & Ancient
review:
Here is among the last of the original Lion Knight badged sets renamed 'Crusaders'. I think my catalogue called this set 'Haunted Castle' which seems much more suitable.

Minifigure Rating:

[··][··][··][··][··]

  • Plate armour.
  • Superb prints.
  • Royal lady hat.
  • Glowing ghost.

The knights display bright, contrasting colours with the grey armour. The royal lady has a unique print, skirt brick and wonderful princess hat, while the black helmeted archers are stunning in silvery plated jerkins brandishing dark grey 'lethal' looking crossbows. The usual overly bright legs are mostly black for a more authentic dark leathery look. Guards come as would be expected with a brown spear and axe and the wonderful ghost makes an appearance to chase everyone around. Despite the lemon yellow, the alternate lion shield improves variation. One knight gets a lance with a blue and red flag banner that's repeated further on.

The horses are geared up, one with an excellent caparison - probably for a captain, while the other knight gets a dark horse for his darker aspect. 

Ancient Bastion
Many lambast these raised baseplate smaller castles for their inferiority to the classics. I believe they achieve what they set out to which is a different kind of medieval building. where to begin? The model gets an overall crumbly old feel as if its a place that could be deserted unless needed by circumstance. The base gets among the best prints around with multiple grey grass edged boulders, rocks and a detailed cobbled track on the ramp. Some vertically inverted slopes hug the diagonal shape of this ramp to make a sturdy pillared and arched edge toward plated ground of the gateway to hold the drawbridge hinges via a technic axle. When topped by the grey arches, this entrance gets a solid base and looks great though it sadly hides some of the best cobbles detail.

The hollow gets an inner build that includes steps down to a trap door dungeon or treasury as a brown chest is included with a yellow (gold) goblet and 'coins'. A small shame that without an arch used in the centre of the hollow, it blocks off a dead space which could have extended the secrecy or been made more of for dungeon effects. The lower wall gets battlements pretty early on as a perimeter wall that by way of diagonal bricks makes a pleasant defensive border.

Pillars and panels make extensive lower internal and external walls with a black unit and barred gate for a jail. Massive brown gates slam shut on the front to make an imposing entrance but you may miss having a portcullis. Archways feature throughout so a lot of style emerges creating a great atmosphere for kids to immerse themselves in. The small front gothic roofed box window is a favourite section.

Upstairs a trick trap door is available to dispense the poor maiden straight downstairs again while a lantern lit balcony is accessed via the stone printed and window paneled tower. A heavy  black gate can 'clang' shut across the back access point so if this is the actual rear wall, its pretty draughty. A small conifer and medium deciduous tree grow in the grounds with lanterns and spears available for inhabitants. The gatehouse remains a short front tower to some extent with the rear rising above it, both smartly decorated with red and blue uniform double flags, just like the knight which is a nice touch. The top tower also gets a double crossbow firing point while the gatehouse has a winch for the drawbridge with the essential black string. With a black carrion bird resident, the happy medieval folk can move in with their bright colours contrasting against the dark gothic bastion and its characterful grounds.

The rear of the box may reveal what other models are suggested but areas I'd rather explore are, a portcullis if possible, internalised doors, a more open dungeon and a higher build, drawn in from the edges. Perhaps a project for a for a rainy day.

Friendly Tower Of Darkness
I found this set hard to compare to predecessors yet it ticks almost every box and is a wonderful design reminiscent of what helped make early Castle such a high quality, popular and enduring theme. Identifying a minor misgiving I'd mention the base. While I think the raised base landmass and print work well, it slightly sacrificed brick count and for the price and has an unusual shape. This is merely a quibble, leaving the knights to go forth and write the history books. A well thought out alternative castle, brilliant model and collectable set.

author: joee
title: Christmas in 1990 was the best Christmas ever!
review:
This was second Castle for the Lion Knights (being redubbed as the Crusaders a year later) and came with a 8 figures including a ghost and maiden with detailed face.

    Pros

  • Great variety of figures. With two euro armour knights, 2 pikemen, 2 archers (w/ new crossbows), a ghost and maiden there was a ton different and new figures for such a set. Compared to the usual 2 knight and 4 soldiers for a medium sized castle.

  • Playability. The set came with the standard drawbridge/gate and dungeon, but has many bonus features including a trap door, secret front entrance, crossbow turret on top and a hidden treasure hold (or even secret basement entrance depending on your imagination). The open concept was also a change as your figures never seemed to cluttered when playing. It even had a somewhat split in playing with the tower/main entrance as one part and the courtyard as another making it seem like two different sets.

  • New pieces and unique pieces. The set featured many new (at the time) pieces with the ghost, large doors brown doors, crossbows, maiden, brown oak tree, euro armour and visored helmets which were a real treat. Also the maiden and the black bird are unique to this set.

  • Excellent Build.  This set took my 3 hours to build as an 8 year old and was challenging and not repetitive. It is very sturdy too once built.

    Cons

  • The outer wall on the courtyard seems rather low and feels like more could have been done. Granted it does give the set a nice openess, but adding another tower in one of the corners would have gone a long way

  • Though the set can be connected to older Castle sets via the technic pin, when connected the walls do not line up and it seems like it was an afterthought to add it on.

The set on the whole marks the end of the classic castle sets of the 80s (it does include the technic pin for attachment to older sets), and is a stepping stone for the newer sets that were to be the standard in the 90s, with its raised baseplate and hidden features. Due to this it can be grouped with either era and also is somewhat polarizing to many for it's lack of belonging to either era. Does that in itself make a bad set of? Of course not! I find it combines many of the good qualities of both eras. This was the first castle I ever owned and was at the perfect age for it. As such it will always be one of my most cherished sets and goes down as the best Christmas present I have ever received.

author: T79
title: Not on the same level as #6080
review:
This was the last lego castle me and my brothers had before we stopped playing with and hence receiving/buying lego sets. As such it didn't see as much use as the venerable #6080 King's Castle and is in much better condition still, so no replacement needed here. It also means less memories of this one, it still was played with and liked although it had some obvious flaws. Especially when compared to #6080 which, given the numbering, seems like the logical set to compare it to.

Box/Instructions

Those flaws begin with the box, actually. While the alternative designs on the box of #6080 were fantastic, those on the box of this castle never did that much to me and I don't remember ever trying to create one of them. The instructions themselves are much like those of #6080: the same format, a picture of the set on the front page, the minifigures on page 2 and building the set (and nothing more) on the subsequent 14 pages. The build itself takes 20 steps or about 20 pieces per step, so just as with #6080 this game of 'spot-the-numerous-differences-in-every-step' was too hard for my children alone, fortunately dad was there to help!

Parts

Another letdown, in comparison with #6080 this castle seemed to offer a lot less (comparing the piece count you can see that is correct: 672 for #6080, 435 for #6081). And even then, while #6080 has thirty wall panels #6081 has four (plus six corner walls, but that still only amounts to a third). It looks like the raised baseplate swallowed a lot of the budget here. That said the baseplate was well received, we had several of these and one of the fondest memories I still have is creating a big landscape with two of these baseplates connected by a bridge (just so some pirate cannons could blow it up, of course). I never liked the big 2 x 6 x 7 frame and prison door, I much preferred the smaller prison door from #6080. Nor did I like the small 2 x 2 winch without handle, again preferring the 2 x 4 x 2 winch with handle from #6080. That isn't to say there aren't any good parts though: the big doors, the black bird and a lot of arches but it doesn't feel like there is enough to build a big castle.

Minifigures

Another disappointment, really. Going from twelve minifigures and four horses in #6080 to eight minifigures and two horses is a real downgrade, two knights and four guards are definitely not enough for a castle this size! Granted, the minifigures that are included are nice, especially the lady with a blue 2 x 2 x 2 slope brick as dress and a feminine face, the first non-standard legs and face in our castles! A glow-in-the-dark ghost (our first) was a welcome addition at the time. Both knights have the new helmets with visors and the additional armour piece (one even has the ever-coveted barding for his horse) but they don't even get a separate plume colour but use a different plume on the same sprue wheel! It used to be so that every plume came in a sprue of three so, in #6080 with four knights each with a different plume colour you had twelve plumes in total. Here you get three... It's probably a bit symptomatic for the entire set, it feels like 'not enough'. We did like the crossbows and you get a lot of those here, though.

The build

This is at least a saving grace here, the build is rather pleasing. It's fun to build up an arcade on the side and have some part of the gatehouse follow the shape of the baseplate to make it look like it is built partially in the hill. The opening front window, while rather useless, does look very nice although on the inside of the gatehouse the (supposedly hidden) ghost can be clearly seen spoiling any surprise for minifigures inside. And I definitely liked the way the wall panels are used to create a second line of defence, so if the gates are breached there is still a wall there. Although the designers themselves seemed to know the (too) low wall surrounding the courtyard is the real problem as the crenellations face that way. And I also liked the deciduous tree built like a palm tree, that was inspiring: we had several palm trees and now they could also be used as normal trees!

The completed model

The box really shows off the best angle here, as overall the 'fortress' is just too open to be really called a fortress: big open windows on the lower level of the tower (I also would have liked smaller doors to close the tower to go better with the inside wall, so attackers that broke through the gate or overran the ridiculously low courtyard wall could still be held at bay. And speaking of a courtyard, there isn't any. Where the knights have to stable their horses is anyone's guess, maybe that's why the tower is left open? The reinforced, barred window is also a weird choice for what appears to be the lady's chamber. Is she a captive here? Is this a room-sized chastity belt perhaps? And the arcade on the side looks nice but hardly looks like a formidable defensive position (again), also this wall does not match any of the earlier castle sets even though there is the usual 1 x 2 technic brick with hole to connect those sets (on a rather random position, to boot). The decision to store some spears outside the walls can be seen as rather poor, too. On a final note, the lack of a portcullis is obvious. Another level on the gatehouse (and on the tower, and on the curtain walls) would be needed for this so again, more parts. The doors don't work too well with the drawbridge however, as the string blocks the gate from opening completely (or closing, if they are completely open) as can even be see on the picture.

Overall opinion

One can not help but feel that so much more would have been possible with this, the dominant feeling here is 'not enough': not enough parts (walls), not enough minifigures, not enough fortification. Although this review is a lot more negative than really necessary, it still looks very nice (the raised baseplate adds some much needed height to it) and playability is high: treasure cellar, prison, gate, ghost, lady... room for a tale or two to be told. And with some extra castle parts this really can be made a lot better, it's just such a pity that it appears the designers had to compromise so much on this. If the same piece and minifigure count from #6276 Eldorado Fortress or even #6080 could have been used on this castle this would have been a really great set! And true enough, a few years later Lego came out with #6086 Black Knight's Castle which manages to do exactly that and is so much better for it. In the end I was torn between giving this a 'three' or 'four' as overall rating, despite its flaws I still gave it a 'four' for the possibilities but only barely.

author: HomeOnTheRange
title: Ghost still glows in the dark after 32 years!
review: I recently pulled out this set from my childhood stash to play with my own children.  I remembered enjoying this set with my brother as a child.  However, I had forgotten how many clever details it has.  The instructions were a bit sparse and I had to take it apart a couple of times because I realised I'd used the wrong combination of pieces so was coming up short.  There is a drawbridge that you can raise and lower by turning the little wheel (still intact and working 32 years later!).  There is a hidden door to the right of the main large wooden doors (these wooden doors are cool too).  There is a trap door in the upper floor of the castle with a black rod that when pushed in prevents the figure from falling through the trap door.  When pulled out, the trap door can open.  There is a black cage style door on the back of the tower (upper level) cleverly constructed out of the poles and other pieces (would be possible to recreate in other colours with other sets which is cool.  On the main floor there is a little one figure dungeon and a trap door in the lower level to hide the ghost or the treasure.  The ghost is a minifigure with a glow in the dark piece over it.  I was surprised to find that after charging it up with light (using the flashlight function on my phone was most efficient), it glowed in the dark well--32 years later!  The base plate is really cool with the green hillside and the multiple pebble colour.  There are many minifigures and horses with cool saddles and other decorative items.  The set can be played with by multiple children at the same time.  One advance since 1990 is that now my kids have it next to the 1987 emergency treatment center.  I saw today that the princess is an inpatient and the knight is on a stretcher in the exam room being evaluated by the doctor and nurse.
